bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, June 11, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Blossom Reed of his efforts to determine the value of her father's books.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, June 11, 1953
div1.opener:
June 11, 1953
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I am most apologetic for my delay in the matter of the books. I have been
constantly on the go and have been excessively busy; my work also was inter-
rupted recently by an annoying respiratory infection. But let me give you
this report.

I was in New York for just a morning about a month ago and got in touch with
Miss Benjamin, one of the leading autograph dealers in New York. I did not
have the books with me but I told her of them; however I did not mention
your name (yet). She told me what I was afraid I would hear, namely that an
autographed book, unless the book itself is of marked value, constitutes
hardly more than an autograph and is of considerably less value than an
autographed letter, which is the lowest item in the scale of holographic
material. Of course your father's local address adds a little to the value
more than if he had simply written his name.

Without seeing the books, Miss Benjamin made a tentative offer (which she
reserved the right to change up or down) of “about $10 a volume.” She said,
“Of course I can't say untill I see the books or know what they are and can
see whether I could sell them for $20 or $25 each. Essentially, they are
merely autographs.” Apparently such dealers expect to make 100 per cent
profit when they can sell things. I know of course that every now and then
they sell things that they have had in their stock for quite a while at
lower prices of one to ten dollars each. I have now sent her the formal
list of the books. The books are safely still in my possession. I don't
want to send them to anyone until they give me a specific offer or show
greater interest. Incidentally, I was a little disappointed to note that
the 5th volume of the five-volume series does not have your father's name
or any inscription.

Secondly, I have enlisted the help of our head librarian here at the Mayo
Clinic who will help me find out the value of the books simply as books,
medical or otherwise.

I have also written to Goodspeeds, of Boston, one of the outstanding book
or letter stores in the country. If their offers are not satisfactory, I
will write to other companies and of course transmit all of the offers to
Mrs. Blossom Reed
- 2 -
June 11, 1953
you who shall decide where they will go. In the meantime, rest assure that
without knowing anything about their commercial value, I will certainly
match the tentative offer of Miss Benjamin. Just for my own pleasure and
interest I will guarantee you what she suggested.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
